title: Generally what is the cheapest color of plastic? : r/plastic - Reddit
body: Aka no colorant added. Also depending on the plastic that can be crystal clear, milky clear, beige, black, amber. Most plastics start in a tan or beige color (although a few are clear). So in theory, uncolored should be your cheapest. But black is usually done with carbon black, which is very cheap as well.
readable_content:
- Andrew-Wang (2020-12-08): Black or dark grey
- la_mecanique (2020-12-08): Black is usually carbon additive which is the cheapest, but also black can cover up the use of cheaper resins like unsorted recycled pellets or regrind. Also making the product cheaper to produce.
- WiscoAstro (2020-12-08): Black for sure. I guess technically gray because you’ll just use less black colorant.
- Vivid or bold yellows are also very expensive and difficult to manage since heavy metals are not allowed in colorants anymore.
- bazamaphone (2020-12-08): Natural. Aka no colorant added.
- ptc075 (2020-12-08): Most plastics start in a tan or beige color (although a few are clear). So in theory, uncolored should be your cheapest. But black is usually done with carbon black, which is very cheap as well. I've never heard of it reducing the price below the natural color however.
On the expensive side, it comes down to colors that need to overwhelm the basic color. So if your material is dark tan naturally, making it bright white (or bright pink) requires a lot of pigment.
